questions.question_text: A storage server with three drives was reporting errors indicating the array was in degraded mode, but the stored files were still accessible. A technician went to the server room to troubleshoot the error message. Which of the following RAID configurations did the technician MOST likely find?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
"RAID 5 requires a minimum of three drives, and it uses block-level striping with distributed parity. If two drives fail, data loss can occur and the array will be in degraded mode."

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer is C

Selected Answer: D
SATA is the most common drive interface for ITX-sized motherboards. It is also the most cost-effective option for RAID 5 arrays.

In this scenario, SATA drives are the most likely choice because they are commonly available, support RAID configurations, and are suitable for ITX-sized systems. SATA drives can be easily connected to the motherboard using SATA cables, making them a practical option for building a computer with a RAID 5 array.

Option D. SATA is the correct answer in this scenario.

questions.question_text: A technician is building a new computer for a customer. The computer must use an ITX-sized motherboard and have a RAID 5 array with all drives using the same interface. Which of the following drive types will the technician MOST likely utilize?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is right.

The wattage rating of the power supply determines the amount of power it can deliver to the components of the PC. It is crucial to ensure that the new power supply has an adequate wattage rating to meet the power requirements of the PC's components, including the graphics card, CPU, and other peripherals.
So C

questions.question_text: Which of the following should a user do FIRST when upgrading the power supply on a gaming PC?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Looking in the book CompTIA A+ page 181 in the cram quiz it is explained:
Question: 
Which type of cable would you use if you were concerned about EMI?
" STP (shielded twisted pair) is the only cable listed here that can reduce electro magnetic interference. However, fiber optic cable is another good solution, though it is more expensive and more difficult to install."

So, it should be B according to the book.

comments.content: which book is it are you reading? thanks

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Def shielded cat6

Selected Answer: B
Cat 6 is Shielded and is not as Expensive as Fiber

C. Plenum Cat 5e

Plenum-rated Cat 5e cables are designed for use in spaces with air circulation, such as the plenum spaces in buildings. They have a protective coating that helps reduce the impact of EMI and provide reliable network connectivity. Cat 5e cables are suitable for many common networking scenarios and offer a good balance between performance and cost.

While shielded Cat 6 cables (Option B) can also provide protection against EMI, they are generally more expensive than Cat 5e cables. Coaxial cables (Option A) are not as common for typical office network installations, and multimode fiber (Option D) is usually more expensive than copper cables.

Therefore, for a cost-effective solution that maintains good performance and addresses EMI concerns, Plenum Cat 5e would be a suitable choice.

comments.content: Plenum has nothing to do with EMI, it's cabling that's rated for fires, it's fire-resistant and low smoke.

discussion.content:
Chat GPT Answer:
B. Shielded Cat 6

Shielded Cat 6 (Category 6) cable is designed to provide protection against electromagnetic interference (EMI). It is a cost-effective solution that offers good performance for typical office network environments. The shielding helps reduce the impact of external interference on the network signal, making it a suitable choice when dealing with sporadic network connectivity issues caused by EMI. While other options like Multimode fiber or Plenum Cat 5e may also provide EMI resistance, they might be more expensive or not as cost-effective for a standard office setting.

comments.content: ChatGPT is killin me. When I plugged it in there, it said Coax...I wasn't even considering that one :'( If I get this question I may go with the cat6, even though it seems we cannot all agree on the answer here.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Multimode fiber but I have to say is not good price... in order do not sacrifice performance once I don't know how much speed they have I will advise to fiber always... single mode for example is not super expensive ..

Selected Answer: B
The "MOST cost-effective" cable medium that can help mitigate EMI without sacrificing system performance would be Shielded Cat 6 cable.
Fiber optic cables, including multimode fiber, are excellent at resisting EMI. However, they are generally more expensive to install and terminate compared to copper cables. Fiber is often used for long-distance connections or where extremely high bandwidth is required.

The correct answer is D because it's the only one that can solve the problem "without sacrificing system performance". EMI doesn't affect fiber. B is cost effective but cannot eliminate EMI completely.

Selected Answer: B
Yeah , changing whole cabling to fiber will be more effective ..

Selected Answer: B
It says most cost effective, so it's Shielded Twisted Pair over Fiber, which is much more expensive.

comments.content: I do follow you on YouTube and I have learned a lot from you. Thanks for clarifying here.

discussion.content:
The answer is "Shielded Cat6" in this instance but yes, Fiber could also work, it's just to dang flippen expensive. Fiber for those that don't know yet, is actually completely immune to EMI since it does not work with copper, it works with glass and light that reflects.

I see "Coaxile" is also listed as an answer. That believe it or not is actually also like using "STP". It also has a shield and is somewhat immune to EMI like STP cable BUT....Coaxile cable is very old technology and you would be sacrificing "performance/speed" and the question specifically states you don't want to do that so yes, the answer is STP.

I've been training the A+ courses for almost 2 decades now and wrote the exams more times than I can remember so I can really tell you when it's the one or the other.

Feel free to check out my Youtube channel "BurningIceTech" where I give free IT training including for the A+ course

The term “cost effective” means producing good results without costing a lot of money12. In other words, something that is cost effective provides good value for the money spent. Cost effectiveness can be measured by comparing the benefits and costs of different alternatives and choosing the one that has the highest benefit-cost ratio3.

The Key Word is "cost-effective" best result for the money spent. Therefor the answer is D

questions.question_text:
A technician is receiving reports that the entire office sporadically loses network connectivity throughout the day. The technician determines the root cause to be
EMI. Which of the following cable mediums would be the MOST cost effective without sacrificing system performance?

choices.C: Clear the temporary files on the workstation's boot drive.
choices.D: Use a hypervisor to adjust the resource allocation.
choices.B: Upgrade to the latest DDR5 modules.
choices.A: Increase the ECC memory timings in the BIOS.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The answer is D. Use a hypervisor to adjust the resource allocation.

A hypervisor is a software layer that enables virtualization and allows multiple virtual machines to run on a single physical machine. With a hypervisor, the technician can modify the resource allocation, including the amount of RAM assigned to the virtual workstation.

By adjusting the resource allocation through the hypervisor, the technician can increase the amount of RAM available to the virtual workstation, allowing it to run more efficiently and handle larger workloads.

Option D. Use a hypervisor to adjust the resource allocation is the correct answer in this scenario.

questions.question_text: A technician needs to increase the available RAM on a virtual workstation. Which of the following should the technician do?
